article.name: GCC High Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual
article.title: GCC High Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual
article.body:
The Government Community Cloud (GCC) High Phish Alert Button (PAB) for Microsoft 365 enables your users to easily report suspicious emails, strengthening your organization's defense against sophisticated phishing attacks. Built for the highly regulated GCC High environment, this PAB operates seamlessly within these security-enhanced infrastructures.

Note:The GCC High PAB does not support mobile devices.

Prerequisites

Before you install the GCC High PAB, your organization will need to have one of the following mail servers:

  • Microsoft 365
  • Microsoft Outlook 2019 or 2021 for Mac with either Exchange 2019 or Microsoft 365.

If you have a proxy server, you’ll need to connect to all of the following to bypass the proxy server or proxy authentication:

  • outlook.office365.us
  • outlook.office.us
  • us.pab.knowbe4.com, eu.pab.knowbe4.com, or ca.pab.knowbe4.com, depending on your KnowBe4 instance.

You’ll also need to enable and configure the PAB from your KnowBe4 console Account Settings page before following the steps in this article.

Important: Contact our support team to enable GCC High PAB for your account. Then follow the steps below to install it.

Enable Permissions in Your KSAT Console

Before installing the GCC High PAB for Microsoft 365, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Click on your email address in the top-right corner of the page, then select Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to Account Integrations > Phish Alert.
  4. Select the Enable Phish Alert toggle.
  5. Select your PAB instance.
  6. From the Select PAB Version drop-down menu, select GCC High Hybrid PAB

  7. Scroll down and click Authorize NAA-SSO for GRAPH APIs. You’ll be redirected to the Microsoft 365 login page.

  8. Log in to your Microsoft 365 account using your admin credentials.
  9. Once you log in, the Permissions requested pop-up window will display. Read the permissions, then click Accept

  10. After you accept the permissions, the GRAPH Authorization Successful window will display. Click Back to PAB Configuration to return to the Phish Alert settings.

  11. Click the download icon next to the PAB manifest for Microsoft products option to download the PhishAlertManifestGCCHigh.xml file.

    Note:Each Phish Alert Button (PAB) XML manifest file is unique to the KSAT console based on where it's downloaded. So, if you manage multiple KSAT consoles, you'll need to download and install the correct manifest file for each console separately.

Install the GCC High PAB in Microsoft 365

Note: GCC High environments have a different M365 Admin console and do not have access to the Office store. For additional information, see Microsoft's documentation.

Follow the steps below to install the GCC High PAB in your Microsoft 365 account.

  1. In a new browser tab, log in to your Microsoft 365 admin center.
  2. From the navigation menu on the left side of the page, navigate to Settings > Add-ins.
  3. On the Add-ins page, click Deploy Add-in.
  4. In the Deploy a new add-in pop-up window, click Next.
  5. Click Upload custom apps.

  6. Select I have the manifest file(.xml) on this device. Then, click Choose File and upload the PhishAlertManifestGCCHigh.xml file.
  7. Click Upload to install the GCC High PAB.

  8. From the Configure add-in pop-up window, select which users will have access to the GCC High PAB and which method you want to use to deploy the PAB.

    Important:We recommend allowing all users to access the PAB and using the Fixed deployment method.

  9. Click Next. Additional app permissions will display.
  10. Once you’ve read the permissions, click Save.

  11. The Deploy Phish Alert pop-up window will confirm that the add-in has successfully deployed. Then, click Next.

  12. The Announce add-in pop-up window will open and display a message about Microsoft’s announcement recommendations.
    Note:After you install and deploy the PAB, you might receive an email from your mail service provider that contains information you can use to help you announce the PAB add-in to your users. KnowBe4 does not send the email about the PAB's intended usage and benefits.

  13. Click Close.

images.alt:
The image displays the **Account Settings** page within the KnowBe4 security platform, specifically focused on **Account Integrations** and **Phish Alert** settings.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The primary page title is **Account Settings**.
*   A left-hand navigation pane is active, showing the path: **Account Integrations > Phish Alert**.
*   Other integration options listed include SAML, API, PhishER, Webhooks, Second Chance, and PasswordIQ.
*   The main content area is titled **Account Integrations**.

**Content Details - SAML Section:**
*   A section titled **SAML** is visible.
*   SAML Settings are displayed with a red badge labeled **Disabled**.

**Content Details - Phish Alert Section:**
*   A section titled **Phish Alert** is visible.
*   A toggle switch labeled **Enable Phish Alert** is highlighted and appears to be activated (blue background).
*   A related link, **See PAB User Activity**, is present.
*   The main settings panel is open under a sub-header labeled **Settings**.
*   A dropdown menu prompts the user to **Select PAB Version**.
    *   The currently selected value is **GCC High Hybrid PAB**. (This selection is explicitly marked by an orange arrow in the image).
*   A button labeled **Set as Default** is present below the PAB version selector, accompanied by a help icon (?).
*   The bottom section starts displaying fields for custom settings, including **Setting Name** and **Icon**, with options to browse and upload a file for the icon. A generic phishing icon (envelope with a hook) is partially visible in the corner.
images.context: lect PAB Version drop-down menu, select GCC High Hybrid PAB

images.alt:
The image displays a segment of a web page listing technical resources.

**Context:** The heading identifies the resource as the "PAB manifest for Microsoft products (PhishAlertManifestGCCHigh.xml)."

**UI Elements/Actions:**
1.  **View Guide:** A blue hyperlink preceded by a guide icon.
2.  **Download:** A blue hyperlink preceded by a download icon.
3.  **Targeted Action:** A separate blue hyperlink, "Authorize NAA-SSO for GRAPH APIs," is highlighted by a large, horizontal orange arrow pointing towards the text.

**Function:** The screenshot illustrates access points for a manifest file, associated documentation, and a required authorization step for configuring NAA-SSO integration with Microsoft GRAPH APIs.
images.context: You’ll be redirected to the Microsoft 365 login page.

images.alt:
This image displays a standard Microsoft organizational consent prompt titled **"Permissions requested"** for a third-party application named **"Phish Alert Button"** (with obscured publisher details). The prompt requires administrative review for organization-wide permission granting.

**Key UI Elements and Text:**

1.  **Header:** Microsoft logo and "Microsoft" branding.
2.  **Title:** "Permissions requested" with the subtitle "Review for your organization."
3.  **Application Context:** The application name is "Phish Alert Button."
4.  **Critical Warning:** A bolded statement explicitly reads: **"This application is not published by Microsoft."**
5.  **Requested Permissions:** The application requests the following seven permissions, indicated by checkmark-style icons:
    *   Read user mail
    *   Read user and shared mail
    *   Read and write access to user mail
    *   Read and write user and shared mail
    *   Send mail as a user
    *   Send mail on behalf of others
    *   Sign in and read user profile
6.  **Disclaimer Text:** Explains that acceptance grants the app access for all users in the organization and bypasses future user prompts. It also contains a critical alert: **"The publisher has not provided links to their terms for you to review."**
7.  **Management Link:** Users can change permissions at `https://myapps.microsoft.com`, followed by an actionable link "Show details."
8.  **Suspicion Report Link:** A linked prompt asking, "Does this app look suspicious? Report it here."
9.  **Action Buttons:** Two call-to-action buttons are present:
    *   **Cancel** (Gray, secondary action)
    *   **Accept** (Blue, primary action)
images.context: Read the permissions, then click Accept

images.alt:
A technical description of the image follows:

This image displays a success confirmation screen within a web application interface, confirming the completion of an API authorization process.

**Header Section:**
*   **Title:** The main heading in bold, black text is "GRAPH Authorization Successful".
*   **Navigation Link:** In the upper right corner, a blue hyperlink with a preceding left arrow icon reads "Back to PAB Configuration".

**Content Section (Confirmation Message):**
The body of the screen contains a confirmation and informational message in standard gray text:
1.  **Confirmation Text:** "Thank you for authorizing the use of Graph APIs for your Phish Alert Button (PAB). All PABs in your domain will now be able to use the Graph APIs provided the environment supports it."
2.  **Support Contact:** A follow-up line provides contact information: "If you have any questions, please email us at support@knowbe4.com". The email address is formatted as a blue hyperlink.

**Context:**
The screen confirms successful integration or authorization of Graph APIs, likely related to Microsoft Graph, for a Phish Alert Button (PAB) feature provided by the vendor KnowBe4.

The image displays a user interface segment providing access to a specific file and associated actions.

**Context and Asset Identifier:**
The primary text identifies the resource as the "PAB manifest for Microsoft products," followed by the exact filename in parentheses: `PhishAlertManifestGCCHigh.xml`.

**Primary UI Elements and Links:**
Immediately below the asset identifier are two related resource actions presented as blue hyperlinks:
1.  **View Guide:** Preceded by an icon of an open book, indicating access to documentation.
2.  **Download:** Preceded by a download icon (a down arrow into a tray).

**Instructional Indicator:**
A large, solid orange arrow points directly to the "Download" hyperlink, emphasizing this as the primary or required action.

**Secondary UI Element:**
The final line displays a separate, distinct blue hyperlink for system configuration: "Authorize NAA-SSO for GRAPH APIs."
images.context: g> option to download the PhishAlertManifestGCCHigh.xml file.

The image displays a modal dialog box for deploying an add-in, overlaid on a darkened application interface.

**Header and Context:**
*   **Title:** "Deploy a [redacted] add-in" (Bold font).

**Deployment Options:**

*   **Descriptive Text:** "Create a new web application, or upload an add-in / integration for Office."

**Footer Controls:**

*   **Control:** A button labeled "Cancel" is located in the bottom left corner, intended to close the dialog without action.

images.alt:
This is a modal configuration window titled **"Configure add-in"** for the **"Phish Alert"** add-in by **KnowBe4, Inc**. The window is structured into two primary configuration sections: Assign Users and Deployment Method.

**Add-in Identity:**
An icon depicting an envelope with the text "H TCT" and a fishing hook/phishing lure is displayed, identifying the **Phish Alert** add-in.

### 1. Assign Users

This section governs user access with the introductory text: "Choose which users will have access to Phish Alert."

Configuration options (radio buttons):

1.  **Everyone** (Selected by default).
2.  **Specific users / groups:** Includes a search field with the placeholder text "Start typing a name to search for users." The search field is preceded by the instruction: "Search for specific users or groups to add or remove."
3.  **Just me.**

### 2. Deployment Method

This section defines how the add-in is delivered to the assigned users.

Configuration options (radio buttons) and their descriptions:

1.  **Fixed (Default)** (Selected by default): "The add-in will be automatically deployed to the assigned users and they will not be able to remove it from their ribbon."
2.  **Available:** "Users may install this add-in by clicking the Get Add-ins button on the home ribbon in Outlook and finding the add-in under the category Admin-managed."
3.  **Optional:** "The add-in will be automatically deployed to the assigned users but they can choose to remove it from their ribbon."

### Action Buttons

The bottom of the window contains two action buttons:

*   **Next** (Highlighted as the primary action).
*   **Cancel**.

A standard 'X' icon is present in the top-right corner to close the window.

This image displays a configuration dialog titled **"Configure add-in,"** detailing the required permissions for the application **"Phish Alert"** by KnowBe4, Inc. A prominent icon depicts an envelope secured by a stylized key/hook labeled 'H' and 'TCT.'

**Contextual Data:**
*   The dialog notes, "This app works with your data."
*   App publisher domain is listed as **"null."**
*   The current user is identified as **"provolone@ancillarycheese.com."**

**Required Permissions (Operations):**
The application requests eight distinct permissions, grouped by function:

1.  **Mail Read/Write Permissions:**
    *   Read user mail (Reads signed-in user's mailbox).
    *   Read user and shared mail (Reads user's and shared mailboxes).
    *   Read and write access to user mail (Create, read, update, delete email; **Does not include permission to send mail**).
    *   Read and write user and shared mail (Create, read, update, delete mail user has permission to access; **Does not include permission to send mail**).

2.  **Mail Send Permissions:**
    *   Send mail as a user (Sends mail as users in the organization).
    *   Send mail on behalf of others (Sends mail as the signed-in user, including sending on-behalf).

3.  **User Profile/Authentication:**
    *   Sign users in (Allows sign-in and access to basic profile information).
    *   View users' basic profile (Allows viewing name, picture, user name, email address).

**Action and Consent:**
A consent statement reads: "By clicking Save, you indicate that you trust this app and agree to its Privacy Policy and Terms of Use." Links to **"Privacy policy"** and **"Terms of Use"** are provided.

The bottom of the dialog contains two action buttons: **Save** (Primary, highlighted) and **Cancel** (Secondary). A close 'X' icon is in the top right corner.

The image displays a modal window confirming the successful deployment of a security add-in, titled "Deploy Phish Alert." A close 'X' button is present in the upper right corner.

**UI Elements and Text Content:**

1.  **Success Banner:** A light green banner with a checkmark indicates successful execution, stating: "Your add-in has been deployed."
2.  **Deployment Details:** The subsequent text confirms an email notification will be sent and emphasizes the critical timing: "It will take up to **12 hours** for the add-in to be displayed on users' ribbons - users might need to relaunch Microsoft 365."
3.  **Instructional Section:** Under the heading "Get started with the add-in," instructions are provided to test the installation by launching the Microsoft 365 app.
4.  **Manual Refresh Path:** Instructions for forcing a refresh are included: "launching the Microsoft 365 app and navigating to the **Insert tab > My Add-ins > Admin Managed**."
5.  **Final Note:** A final, bolded reminder reiterates the delay: "**Outlook add-ins can take up to 12 hours after deployment to become available.**"
6.  **Action Buttons:** The footer contains two action buttons: "Next" (primary, blue-highlighted) and "Close" (secondary).

This image displays a modal dialogue box titled "**Announce add-in**," designed to guide administrators on communicating the deployment of a new software component. A standard close 'X' icon is visible in the top right corner.

**Add-in Identification:**
Below the main title is the specific add-in information, featuring an icon representing an envelope with a security or alert symbol.
*   **Name:** Phish Alert
*   **Developer:** By KnowBe4, Inc

**Content and Context:**
The body text provides a rationale for the announcement: "Studies have shown that adoption of new software is significantly more successful when users are informed and trained..."

A core instruction follows, preceded by a small envelope icon: "Tell users about their new add-in by sending out an informative email."

Suggested topics for the announcement email are listed:
*   How this add-in can make their work easier and quicker
*   Where they can find the add-in
*   Who in particular will the add-in be useful for

The final line confirms supporting material delivery: "We’ll send you an email shortly containing content you can use to help you announce the add-in to your users."

**Action Control:**
A persistent footer bar is present at the bottom containing a single functional button:
*   **Button Label:** Close (Standard grey background).
